When a small group of living beings (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it is derived (for example, if it moves above a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return), it often finds itself in a different environment from that in which it was previously.
This new environment has different resources and competitors so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it had before.
The original population has not changed at all, they still need the same adaptations.
As time goes by, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to resemble less and less the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will appear so different that they will no longer be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense according to which the fate of humanity is dictated by a underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technologies.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: technological development itself is a process that transcends cultural and political influences, and technology has an impact on societies that are intrinsically conditioned rather than socially conditioned.
For example, one could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new production methods are developed to reduce the cost of ownership of a car.
The possession of a large number of cars also leads to an increase in road accidents, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat bodily injuries.

Unfortunately, drivers tend to act within a reasonable range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonable coherence and can be mathematically approximated.

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BC, and was used by Phoenicians, Romans and Almohads as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who after having destroyed it had rebuilt it and christened it Casa Branca, abandoned it in 1755 after a earthquake.
The sultan of Morocco rebuilt the city under the name of Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in Morocco for shopping.

Around the old medina, it is easy to find places where you can buy traditional Moroccan products, such as tajines, pottery, leather goods, narguilés and all kinds of trinkets, but that's all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist city located in the eastern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo, near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava of the Nyiragongo volcano which buried most of the city streets, especially the downtown.
Although Goma is reasonably safe, any visit outside of Goma must be researched to understand the ongoing fighting in the North Kivu province.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in northeastern South Africa and runs along the Mozambique border to the east, the Zimbabwean border to the north and the Crocodile River to the south.
The total surface of the park is 19 500 km², divided into 14 ecozones, each of which harbours a specific fauna.
This is one of the most famous amusement parks in South Africa and considered to be the crown jewel of SANParks.
As for all South African national parks, there are daily entry and conservation fees for the park.

The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove belt in the world, stretching 80 km (50 miles) from the coast to the backwaters of Bangladesh and India.
The Sundarbans have been declared UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest located on Indian territory is called the Sundarbans National Park.
The forests, however, are not composed solely of mangrove swamps : they also contain some of the last vestiges of the majestic jungles that once covered the plains of the Ganges.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km², of which about one third is covered by water/marshy areas.
Sundarbans is a national park since 1966, you can find about 400 Royal Bengal tigers and 30,000 spotted deer.

The Oyapock Bridge is a suspension bridge. It spans the Oyapock River to connect the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers are 83 meters high; it is 378 meters long and has two 3.50-meter-wide lanes.

The bridge should be fully operational in September 2017, when the Brazilian customs posts should be completed.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands Pound (FKP) which is equivalent to one pound sterling (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank on the islands located at Stanley, opposite the FIC West store.
The pound sterling is widely accepted throughout the islands, while at Stanley, American dollars and credit cards are also often accepted.
On the nearby islands, credit cards will probably not be accepted, even if British and American currencies may be accepted. Talk to the owners ahead of time to agree on a payment method.
It is almost impossible to exchange money from the Falklands outside the islands, so change it before leaving the islands.

The stirrups are supports for the rider's feet, which hang from each side of the saddle.
